title: Why bother with public health history?

markdown.headingText: Why bother with public health history?
markdown.markdown:
PUBHLTH 405 Social Epidemiology of Infectious Disease University of Michigan School of Public Health

Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="400" height="100"} ## Agenda - Review and discuss pieces by Fairchild et al. and Krishnan et al. - Deeper dive on pathogen project topics. - Review plans for next meeting (after Labor Day) ## How do we make sense of the role of public health history in the present day? - What did Hibbert Hill say the old vs. new public health was about in 1913? - How well has this idea aged? - What do you think the EXODUS in the title refers to? - What do you think the authors most value about a historical perspective for making sense of modern public health challenges? - How old does an event need to be to qualify as an object of social historical interest? ## Why should we care about public health history? :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > "History sensitizes us to the interplay of the varied social, political, and economic forces that positioned public health at different moments in time, regardless of the areas of responsibility the field claimed at the time." [@fairchild2010] ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![Controversial in 1918, controversial now...](../images/20220831124132.png) ::: ::: ## What's new...is old? :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > "For Hill, to improve the health of the nation, one had to begin changing behavior a single person at a time." :::{.fragment fragment-index=1} > "The field had to abandon universalist environmental solutions‚Äî introducing pure water, sewage systems, street cleaning ‚Äî and begin focusing on training people how to live cleaner, more healthful lives." [@fairchild2010] ::: ::: :::{.column width=50%} :::{.fragment fragment-index=1} ![Ruh roh!](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4pTreSBakbwZTEeA/giphy.gif) ::: ::: ::: ## Scientific advancement and social progress do not always sync up :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > "New medical technologies ‚Äî antibiotics, vaccines, psychotropic medications, and a host of other clinical interventions‚Äîprovided apolitical means of attacking disease without disrupting the social order." [@fairchild2010] ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![Medical innovation often takes place in the context of more cyclical patterns of human history](../images/20220831104346.png){width=70%} ::: ::: ## What lessons can we draw from a historical pandemic to make sense of a new one? :::{.columns} :::{.column width=40%} - What were the dominant patterns of race/ethnic differences in 1918 influenza infection and mortality? - How do contemporary causal explanations of these patterns differ from those offered by physicians at the time? - How have the 2020-era recommendations and predictions from the big table in; this piece aged? ::: :::{.column width=60%} ![Table from Krishnan et al. of historical insights and early-COVID implications](../images/20220830150449.png) ::: ::: ## How did some physicians and researchers explain racial disparities in 1918 influenza mortality at the time? > "[W]hite public health figures like Chicago Commissioner of Public Health John Dill Robertson, used these findings to justify biological determinism, concluding that ‚Äúthe colored race was more immune than the white to influenza." [@krishnan2020] ## A historical perspective can be forward-looking üî≠ :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > ‚ÄúWe can choose to walk through it, dragging the carcasses of our prejudice and hatred, our avarice, our data banks and dead ideas...Or we can walk through lightly, with little luggage, ready to imagine another world. And ready to fight for it.‚Äù [@roy2020] ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![Race, class, and politics are essential to understanding the run-up and response to SARS-CoV-2 around the world](../images/trump_modi_covid.png) ::: ::: # Getting Acquainted with Project Pathogens ü¶† ## Getting to know ü¶† - I am going to break you into 10 groups each with an assigned pathogen from the [list](https://zelnotes.io/teaching/PUBHLTH405/pathogen+project/Pathogen+Project+Topics) - Spend some time reading up on your group's pathogen - Enter info on the pathogen into this [Google doc](https://goo.gl/maps/zthUMkCy2wDYCvAt8) - Organize your findings into subheadings of Biology, History, and Present/Future - Can be very basic, feel free to paste in images and links to relevant resources. ## Next Time [Outbreak, Epidemic, Pandemic](https://zelnotes.io/teaching/PUBHLTH405/modules/Laying+the+Foundation/3.+Outbreak%2C+Epidemic%2C+Pandemic) ## References
